<p><strong>Last year,</strong> McKinsey conducted a survey of a dozen global supply chain leaders across industry sectors to understand what changes could be expected in IT for supply chain planning over the next five years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b55dc7a7-2460-4e4a-9738-29e4a5af14cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b55dc7a7-2460-4e4a-9738-29e4a5af14cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Maril Destino, Julian Fischer, Daniel Mllerklein, and Vera Trautwein, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/to-improve-your-supply-chain-modernize-your-supply-chain-it">To improve your supply chain, modernize your supply-chain IT</a>, McKinsey, February 9, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> One of the surveys key findings was that 90 percent of respondents expected to overhaul their current planning IT.</p>
<p>In recent years, the COVID-19 pandemic and various destabilizing geopolitical events have made the need to strengthen global supply chains more urgent. Many companies have shifted from manual short-term solutions to longer-term solutions that incorporate advanced technologies, such as advanced prediction and optimization algorithms.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What are advanced planning systems?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Advanced planning systems (APSs) are applications or software that enable industry leaders to plan the end-to-end supply chain and coordinate tasks such as advanced forecasting, demand planning, supplier collaboration, material planning, production planning, distribution planning, and order management (exhibit).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex-sidebar.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Advanced planning systems can enable integrated business planning of the  end-to-end supply chain." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex-sidebar.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Such technologies are not limited to monolithic architectures and are often the result of advanced planning systems (APSs) that combine bespoke advanced-analytics (AA) models for increased functionality (see sidebar What are advanced planning systems?).</p>
<p>In a follow-up survey we conducted with 80 companies involved in digital-planning transformations that focused on the deployment of an APS, we found a wide range of ROI across companies, with the most successful companies achieving returns four times higher than the median.</p>
<p>This article focuses on the recipe that supply chain leaders can use to overcome challenges and achieve the highest impact during their transformations. This winning recipe is designed to support APS-centered digital-planning transformations and to make supply chains more resilient, effective, and efficient.</p>
<h2>The five ingredients of a successful APS transformation</h2>
<p>According to our survey respondents, more than 60 percent of supply chainplanning IT transformations take more time or money than expected or dont achieve anticipated business outcomes. The winning recipe for a successful transformation requires integrating five ingredients to deliver at-scale impact (Exhibit 1). Much as a vehicle needs all of its elements, if one part of the system is missing, the vehicle wont function as intended.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Integrated advanced planning systems transformations require five key ingredients. " src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Linking these five ingredients will require fundamental shifts in the ways of working for organizations undergoing APS transformations. Making these shifts can help organizations achieve their business goals on time and under budget.</p>
<h3>1. Processes and organization: How to defeat the attitude that things have always been done this way</h3>
<p>A digital-planning transformation is not only an IT matter. It is first and foremost a redesign of planning processes, with a significantly higher degree of cross-functional integration. Simply laying new tech on top of old processes misses several opportunities for optimization, including offering value-added services to customers or driving profitability through the coordination of sales and operations.</p>
<p>Companies should understand what good looks like by getting a view of best-practice planning processes, which include demand, supply, logistics, and sales and operations planningas well as the control tower, inventory management, scheduling, and collaboration with suppliers.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: Life sciences company</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>A large global pharmaceutical manufacturer managed to achieve a major inventory reduction, top industry service levels, and improved efficiency through an advanced planning system (APS) transformation. This improvement was made possible by defining overarching standardized end-to-end processes and operating models that were both global and specific to the business units. In particular, the organization worked to change its planning capabilities, such as moving from fragmented to end-to-end planning. Instead of viewing the APS transformation as an IT project and appointing project managers from the business side and IT separately, the organization created a joint team that brought together IT, business leaders, and process consultants. In this way, the organization carried out the APS transformation in parallel with reengineering processes, resulting in agile three-way communication.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>At the outset of the transformation, companies should invest the necessary amount of time into mapping every step of the process in conjunction with bottom-up impact analysis. This can help ensure that any newly implemented process supports the value drivers.</p>
<p>To address process and organization, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar Example: Life sciences company):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Orchestrate processes and automate routine tasks, such as data updates, communication, and stakeholder input gathering.</li>
    <li>Design for critical executive decisions with readily available data and governance that facilitate alignment between commercial, logistics, production, and procurement.</li>
    <li>Enable comprehensive views of important risks and opportunities via root-cause analysisfor example, pegging orders to their raw materials.</li>
    <li>Embed process changes and improvements over several cycles, enabling incremental adoption of the new mindset and process.</li>
    <li>Create transparency for where new processes can be diverted by documenting process exceptions, such as when expediting orders creates supply chain inefficiencies.</li>
    <li>Monitor end-to-end supply chain performance and adherence with real-time dashboards to track system adoption and proper system decision making.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c60ab76e-7e5f-4beb-b703-98a2d1ca1a06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c60ab76e-7e5f-4beb-b703-98a2d1ca1a06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more on improving supply chain performance, see Jan Henrich, Jason Li, Carolina Mazuera, and Fernando Perez, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/future-proofing-the-supply-chain">Future-proofing the supply chain</a>, McKinsey, June 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>By the time the system is ready for transformation, companies should be ready to implement the designed process. Any divergence from the target design state should be monitored for both primary and secondary processes.</p>
<h3>2. Data infrastructure and data management: How to overcome insufficient data readiness</h3>
<p>Digital planning requires four system layers to integrate seamlessly: a system of innovation in which to use machine learning and other innovative solutions, APS as a core planning software (system of differentiation), a system of consolidation where multiple sources are harmonized and consolidated in the data lake, and a system of record where the companys enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems typically have the majority of source data (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Digital planning requires seamless integration of what is typically four system layers." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/the%20winning%20recipe%20for%20transforming%20advanced%20planning%20systems/svgz-the-winning-recipe-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Automated data integration is challenging and should not be underestimated. What makes the difference in terms of impact is the timely availability and quality of the data with which the systems work. Even though most leaders are aware of this issue, we continue to see companies oversimplify the work, overestimate the capacity of their teams or their resources, and lack the necessary accountability for data preparation.</p>
<p>Treating data like a product can reduce the time and effort needed to implement new use cases by as much as 90 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2575de6d-54d7-4216-a042-6c1302819500"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2575de6d-54d7-4216-a042-6c1302819500" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more on what treating data like a product looks like, see Veeral Desai, Tim Fountaine, and Kayvaun Rowshankish, <a href="/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/how-to-unlock-the-full-value-of-data-manage-it-like-a-product">How to unlock the full value of data? Manage it like a product</a>, McKinsey, June 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> On this point, APSs often have a well-defined data model, which is critical to scale the system. Today, companies are capable of preparing 70 percent of the necessary data tables in their own data lake well before the start of the actual transformation.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: Large global agricultural company</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>An agricultural company undertook a supply chain transparency project a year before its advanced planning system (APS) implementation. As part of this project, the company integrated data from various sources into its data lake and built best-practice supply chain dashboards to monitor the data quality. Although project leaders struggled with data issues during the dashboarding project, the company was ultimately able to deliver the APS project ahead of time because it could benefit from the work done before. The company was already using the data via the supply chain dashboards, which improved data quality and timeliness. The time gained could then be invested in improving processes and user interface (UI) design.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Typically, companies build a view or data tables that map to the APS vendor data model. Doing so can derisk future data pipeline issues. Data engineering inside the APS application is not easily accessible by users and can be considered a black box, and data changes upstream will likely cause data pipeline issues in the APS system. Companies therefore will need a hotline to an APS support organization to help them resolve the issues.</p>
<p>To address data integration and architecture, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar Example: Large global agricultural company):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Integrate, contextualize, and harmonize necessary data inside the companys cloud. Build well in advance a view or data tables that map to the APS vendor data model. ERP systems will be the main source of information; however, many companies are running with different ERP systems, and some critical data will likely not reside in the ERP system.</li>
    <li>Set up a system and data architecture to support real-time decision making and optimize load times between local data updates and the APS user system.</li>
    <li>Institute the management of master data. Planning systems are built on master data, and even though old processes might not surface problems, the newer process will almost certainly suffer.</li>
    <li>Review transactional-data accuracy and timeliness. Transactional-data updates should be real time (at the inventory level, for example) and synchronized. In addition, companies should review the accuracy of data related to details such as arrival times and product weights.</li>
</ul>
<h3>3. Planning technologies: How to avoid paying for something that isnt used to its full potential</h3>
<!-- -->
<p>Companies often select an APS vendor based on its industry experience or the number of installations the vendor has done. In a second stage, companies create a checklist of planning functionalities, such as pegging, scenario analysis, and debottlenecking. However, we recommend getting a deeper understanding of the quality of these functionalities and reviewing nonfunctional criteriaincluding ease of use, quality of delivery services, future flexibility, and riskbefore selecting an APS vendor.</p>
<p>Because so many APS transformations are considered IT projects, many companies adopt off-the-shelf APS solutions. Instead, companies should assess how to build a two-level architecture that combines APS technology with AA solutions, such as advanced prediction and optimization algorithms.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: Global metals producer</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>A metals company went through a supply-planning transformation at scale, leveraging advanced planning system (APS) technology. In the design phase, the company concluded that the APS vendors off-the-shelf algorithm would not suffice to achieve the maximum impact for its future-state process because the companys processes were bespoke. The APS vendor had an open architecture that allowed the company to integrate a bespoke optimization algorithm, which serves as the brain behind the supply plan, while all data structures, user interfaces, data flows, and user interactions were supported by the more standard APS solution. As a result, the company achieved maximum impact by integrating its unique operational constraints, as well as its objectives, while leveraging strong APS standardization and automation of planning processes.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Regarding AA solutions, a higher level of customizationand, in some cases, bespoke solutionsis needed. Our experience shows that approximately 50 percent of the value from APS transformations comes from the use of customized AA models in combination with APS systems. This allows for maximum flexibility and predictive accuracy and helps optimization models to best fit planning trade-offs and constraints.</p>
<p>To address planning technologies, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar Example: Global metals producer):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Undergo a thorough vendor selection based on a set of functional and nonfunctional selection criteria, including industry use cases, installs, and product deep-dive sessions.</li>
    <li>Select the right systems integration partner, particularly one that can handle the complexity and customization necessary to fit the companys needs.</li>
    <li>Get an unbiased, high-level view of the envisioned result and map it against the off-the-shelf APS solution. Align on the customization and list requirements that cant be fulfilled.</li>
    <li>Create the mechanism to achieve impact during solution blueprinting and put extra focus on AA solutions. Because these are often the main value drivers, review applicability and customize as needed.</li>
    <li>Synchronize the rollout of the APS and the relevant AA solutions by region or business unit, thus maximizing value creation along the journey, potentially self-funding the entire transformation, and boosting its overall net present value.</li>
    <li>As early as the build phase, test that the technology and its various features are functioning correctly. Company product owners should be the final gate to declaring a feature as complete.</li>
    <li>Take the time to complete system integration testing, user acceptance testing, and hyper-care (the period immediately following a system change that requires elevated levels of support). This will make your system more robust in the long term.</li>
</ul>
<h3>4. Capabilities, mindset, and behaviors: How to avoid the return of old habits</h3>
<p>Best-practice processes are typically designed at the start of a project, but once a company reaches the implementation stage of an APS transformation, the target processes are adjusted and people tend to fall back to old ways of working.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ca0792c-00fd-46b1-9a01-4cc5d8ec2f54"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ca0792c-00fd-46b1-9a01-4cc5d8ec2f54" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> Knut Alicke, Elena Dumitrescu, Markus Leopoldseder, and Ali Sankur, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/digital-supply-chains-do-you-have-the-skills-to-run-them">Digital supply chains: Do you have the skills to run them?</a>, McKinsey, July 6, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This usually occurs when organizations underestimate the importance of establishing the right internal capabilities to drive an enhanced supply chain or when companies have not established processes for adapting mindsets and behaviors to new ways of working.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d995b2ba-019d-4f71-ba4f-8a18381daea7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d995b2ba-019d-4f71-ba4f-8a18381daea7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Knut Alicke, Elena Dumitrescu, and Margarita Protopappa-Sieke, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/transforming-supply-chains-do-you-have-the-skills-to-accelerate-your-capabilities">Transforming supply chains: Do you have the skills to accelerate your capabilities?</a>, McKinsey, March 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To develop talent with more-complex skill profiles, companies can create two new types of capabilities: one with a combination of functional, technical, and leadership competencies to drive performance and another with technical competencies to build, maintain, and develop core AA-model archetypes.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: Semiconductor producer</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>A leading global semiconductor player embarked on a two-year transformation of its supply chain, upgrading the skills of more than 1,000 employees, many of whom had been working in the organization for 20 to 30 years. The company had no systematic capability-building program in place for experienced staff, and the effort in external hiring had not been able to meet the requirements for the transformation. As the company embarked on a comprehensive supply chain transformation, its leaders suspected that success would depend on a significant shift in the skills and mindsets of its staff. By running a detailed assessment of the companys workforce capabilities, the company was able to set up a two-year capability-building road map segmented by target population, functional knowledge, and level of expertise. In doing so, workforce capabilities dramatically increased, and the gap to initial state was closed, ensuring the success of the transformation program.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Next to talent development and capability building, there are three other core elements that embed change into the organization: role modeling management (such as the presence of supply chain and IT directors in key project meetings), embedding change in formal mechanisms (such as disabling old systems), and providing intense support to adopt new ways of working (such as setting up a network of superusers).</p>
<p>To address capabilities, mindset, and behaviors, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar Example: Semiconductor producer):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Set up a company-wide communications strategy across multiple channels. As part of change management, strive to create understanding and model best practices.</li>
    <li>Be a role model of top management by being present in crucial project governance meetings, leading company communication, and regularly discussing capabilities in executive meetings.</li>
    <li>Develop tailored capability-building programs focused on the specific skills needed. Focus on best practices around planning as well as leadership skills and specific APS software skills.</li>
    <li>Blend new competencies, such as data science or data engineering, with training in supply chain management or support from translators who blend functional and digital knowledge.</li>
    <li>Develop a performance management structure that rewards top performers and takes corrective action when performance drops below expectations.</li>
    <li>Combine specific trainings based on learning material from the APS vendor with in-person classroom trainings for a set of superusers.</li>
    <li>Facilitate change management in which process improvements will be made over several cycles, enabling incremental adoption of the new mindset and process.</li>
</ul>
<p>Finally, this type of transformation can have a twofold impact on performance: in addition to the overall improvement of systems and ways of working, the investment in people could generate a substantial return because of increased motivation. Shaping and building solutions that help employees make more effective business decisions in a more efficient way will enable employees to work smarterrather than working harder to manually run routine tasks and failing to address complex economic optimization trade-offs in planning.</p>
<h3>5. Integrated transformation management: How to avoid project delays and working in silos</h3>
<p>Whether a tech-related transformation is for the supply chain or another business function, such transformations are notoriously difficult to get right.</p>
<p>For this reason, value assurance has emerged as a solution for ensuring on-time, on-budget, and on-vision delivery as well as supporting rapid value capture and long-term sustainable impact. Leaders can focus on value-led transformations by implementing guardianship around three distinct, equally important, and mutually reinforcing pillars of responsibility: design, delivery, and value.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f494a53c-3eb9-4dce-98de-4cfbf13e8280"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f494a53c-3eb9-4dce-98de-4cfbf13e8280" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These three principles will be covered in greater detail in a forthcoming article.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Design.</em> Creating a blueprint for success is crucial to effectively managing ingredients of success, such as process and organization, data infrastructure and management, planning technologies, and integrated transformation.</li>
    <li><em>Delivery.</em> Ensuring that system and organizational readiness ultimately stacks up to initial design blueprints, delivery also helps resolve tough design choices regarding customization versus standard system design, enabling rapid end-to-end implementation of the solution across the value chain.</li>
    <li><em>Value.</em> Driving successful change management can help establish a value-focused transformation office to ensure cross-functional stakeholder alignment and prioritize actions.</li>
</ul>
<p>With these points in mind, a necessary component of value assurance is building a multidisciplinary team. When it comes to managing the deployment of a wave itselffor example, planning the blueprint, build, testing, or hyper-care for a certain geography and business unitleaders should set up a strong hands-on team, led by someone who can steer a diverse group of people.</p>
<p>Typically, an advanced planning transformation requires collaboration among at least three to four different companiesfor instance, a planning software company, a systems integrator, an operating-model consultancy, and a middleware company. It is important that together these companies bring the necessary expertise on all different layers of a digital-planning system. This requires a diverse team set up with more than ten different roles, including industry experts, supply chain planners, solution architects, integration architects, solution configurators, data lake engineers, source system IT, middleware experts, and others.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Example: A metal company</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The advanced planning system (APS) implementation for a metal company involved a collaboration among three organizations: the metal company itself, the APS, and the value assurance or integration partner. To ensure that all three companies were working as one team, the collaboration established a single project governance with one overall project manager and one overall project steering committee (with combined business and IT functions). This avoided siloed ways of working and misaligned priorities. The project manager worked hand in hand with the APS technical lead to set the priorities and define business requirements, while the technical lead defined technical requirements, ensured solution quality, and gave input on workload. As a result, the team was able to work in a synchronized way and deliver the project on time.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Several factors make this level of collaboration challenging. To begin, it requires a change in mindsets among buyers and suppliers that may be used to more transactional or even adversarial relationships. And most collaborative efforts need intensive, cross-functional involvement from all sidesa marked change to the normal working methods at many companies.</p>
<p>To address integrated transformation management, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar Example: A metal company):</p>
<ul>
    <li>Set up a project management and project steering committee headed by both IT and the business. Final decision makers, such as the COO and chief technological officer (CTO), can lead the steering committee, removing roadblocks and providing clear direction; project managers can drive top-quality content because of their deep supply chain and ERP expertise.</li>
    <li>Take the time to become one team and carve out time to have fun. Have an in-person kickoff to align on roles and responsibilities, deliverables of blueprinting, and ways of working.</li>
    <li>Establish a project management cadence that involves all parties. Key stakeholders of all companies and departments should be present for daily project check-ins, weekly progress reviews, and monthly steering committees.</li>
    <li>Create clearly defined roles and responsibilities. Summarize team roles and their descriptions on one page and the deliverables per role and project phase on another. Buy-in from senior leaders of each company involved can also help hold everyone accountable.</li>
    <li>Use one project management tool that captures the entire workloadincluding user requirements, user acceptance testing (UAT) or system-integration-testing cases, issues, and change requestsand projects along the implementation timeline. Track progress rigorously and reprioritize when needed.</li>
    <li>Tailor the meeting cadence to what is needed per phase of the projectfor example, blueprinting meetings can vary week by week, while testing meetings can be held daily at predefined times and with a consistent agenda. That said, some phases, such as blueprinting and testing, benefit from face-to-face interaction, while others, such as building, are more remote.</li>
</ul>
<p>Improving cross-functional engagement is a leadership issue. Organizations with the most successful collaboration programs often use a formal approach to managing cross-functional teams, with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This is necessary because a formal approach not only helps ensure that the business does not see the transformation as an IT project but also helps the APS vendor feel accountable for the outcome in terms of its impact on performance and not merely its execution.</p>
<hr>
<p>Old playbooks for transforming supply chain systems are no longer useful, so companies need to think APS transformations through across a broad range of areas. To succeed, it is vital that companies look beyond IT to the transformation process itself: the desired data pipeline, which APS system works best for them, what cultural changes the organization needs, and how collaboration across organizations will work now and in the future.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The winning recipe for transforming advanced planning systems","displayName":"The winning recipe for transforming advanced planning systems","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"e93380bf-ec15-48b2-9492-70f3496ec29f","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The winning recipe for transforming advanced planning systems"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Transforming advanced planning systems"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Most supply chain leaders will overhaul their IT systems for planning in the coming years. This article shows how to increase the chances of success."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"In the coming years, how can supply chain leaders overhaul their IT systems and increase the chances of a successful APS implementation?"},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-20T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLast year,\u003c/strong\u003e McKinsey conducted a survey of a dozen global supply chain leaders across industry sectors to understand what changes could be expected in IT for supply chain planning over the next five years.[[Footnote 1]] One of the survey\u0026rsquo;s key findings was that 90 percent of respondents expected to overhaul their current planning IT.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn recent years, the COVID-19 pandemic and various destabilizing geopolitical events have made the need to strengthen global supply chains more urgent. Many companies have shifted from manual short-term solutions to longer-term solutions that incorporate advanced technologies, such as advanced prediction and optimization algorithms.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eSuch technologies are not limited to monolithic architectures and are often the result of advanced planning systems (APSs) that combine bespoke advanced-analytics (AA) models for increased functionality (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;What are advanced planning systems?\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a follow-up survey we conducted with 80 companies involved in digital-planning transformations that focused on the deployment of an APS, we found a wide range of ROI across companies, with the most successful companies achieving returns four times higher than the median.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article focuses on the recipe that supply chain leaders can use to overcome challenges and achieve the highest impact during their transformations. This winning recipe is designed to support APS-centered digital-planning transformations and to make supply chains more resilient, effective, and efficient.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe five ingredients of a successful APS transformation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to our survey respondents, more than 60 percent of supply chain\u0026ndash;planning IT transformations take more time or money than expected or don\u0026rsquo;t achieve anticipated business outcomes. The winning recipe for a successful transformation requires integrating five ingredients to deliver at-scale impact (Exhibit 1). Much as a vehicle needs all of its elements, if one part of the system is missing, the vehicle won\u0026rsquo;t function as intended.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eLinking these five ingredients will require fundamental shifts in the ways of working for organizations undergoing APS transformations. Making these shifts can help organizations achieve their business goals on time and under budget.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Processes and organization: How to defeat the attitude that \u0026lsquo;things have always been done this way\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA digital-planning transformation is not only an IT matter. It is first and foremost a redesign of planning processes, with a significantly higher degree of cross-functional integration. Simply laying new tech on top of old processes misses several opportunities for optimization, including offering value-added services to customers or driving profitability through the coordination of sales and operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies should understand \u0026ldquo;what good looks like\u0026rdquo; by getting a view of best-practice planning processes, which include demand, supply, logistics, and sales and operations planning\u0026mdash;as well as the control tower, inventory management, scheduling, and collaboration with suppliers.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAt the outset of the transformation, companies should invest the necessary amount of time into mapping every step of the process in conjunction with bottom-up impact analysis. This can help ensure that any newly implemented process supports the value drivers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address process and organization, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: Life sciences company\u0026rdquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOrchestrate processes and automate routine tasks, such as data updates, communication, and stakeholder input gathering.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDesign for critical executive decisions with readily available data and governance that facilitate alignment between commercial, logistics, production, and procurement.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEnable comprehensive views of important risks and opportunities via root-cause analysis\u0026mdash;for example, pegging orders to their raw materials.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEmbed process changes and improvements over several cycles, enabling incremental adoption of the new mindset and process.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate transparency for where new processes can be diverted by documenting process exceptions, such as when expediting orders creates supply chain inefficiencies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMonitor end-to-end supply chain performance and adherence with real-time dashboards to track system adoption and proper system decision making.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy the time the system is ready for transformation, companies should be ready to implement the designed process. Any divergence from the target design state should be monitored for both primary and secondary processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Data infrastructure and data management: How to overcome insufficient data readiness\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDigital planning requires four system layers to integrate seamlessly: a system of innovation in which to use machine learning and other innovative solutions, APS as a core planning software (system of differentiation), a system of consolidation where multiple sources are harmonized and consolidated in the data lake, and a system of record where the company\u0026rsquo;s enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems typically have the majority of source data (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAutomated data integration is challenging and should not be underestimated. What makes the difference in terms of impact is the timely availability and quality of the data with which the systems work. Even though most leaders are aware of this issue, we continue to see companies oversimplify the work, overestimate the capacity of their teams or their resources, and lack the necessary accountability for data preparation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTreating data like a product can reduce the time and effort needed to implement new use cases by as much as 90 percent.[[Footnote 3]] On this point, APSs often have a well-defined data model, which is critical to scale the system. Today, companies are capable of preparing 70 percent of the necessary data tables in their own data lake well before the start of the actual transformation.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eTypically, companies build a view or data tables that map to the APS vendor data model. Doing so can derisk future data pipeline issues. Data engineering inside the APS application is not easily accessible by users and can be considered a black box, and data changes upstream will likely cause data pipeline issues in the APS system. Companies therefore will need a hotline to an APS support organization to help them resolve the issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address data integration and architecture, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: Large global agricultural company\u0026rdquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIntegrate, contextualize, and harmonize necessary data inside the company\u0026rsquo;s cloud. Build well in advance a view or data tables that map to the APS vendor data model. ERP systems will be the main source of information; however, many companies are running with different ERP systems, and some critical data will likely not reside in the ERP system.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSet up a system and data architecture to support real-time decision making and optimize load times between local data updates and the APS user system.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eInstitute the management of master data. Planning systems are built on master data, and even though old processes might not surface problems, the newer process will almost certainly suffer.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eReview transactional-data accuracy and timeliness. Transactional-data updates should be real time (at the inventory level, for example) and synchronized. In addition, companies should review the accuracy of data related to details such as arrival times and product weights.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Planning technologies: How to avoid paying for something that isn\u0026rsquo;t used to its full potential\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies often select an APS vendor based on its industry experience or the number of installations the vendor has done. In a second stage, companies create a checklist of planning functionalities, such as pegging, scenario analysis, and debottlenecking. However, we recommend getting a deeper understanding of the quality of these functionalities and reviewing nonfunctional criteria\u0026mdash;including ease of use, quality of delivery services, future flexibility, and risk\u0026mdash;before selecting an APS vendor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause so many APS transformations are considered IT projects, many companies adopt off-the-shelf APS solutions. Instead, companies should assess how to build a two-level architecture that combines APS technology with AA solutions, such as advanced prediction and optimization algorithms.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eRegarding AA solutions, a higher level of customization\u0026mdash;and, in some cases, bespoke solutions\u0026mdash;is needed. Our experience shows that approximately 50 percent of the value from APS transformations comes from the use of customized AA models in combination with APS systems. This allows for maximum flexibility and predictive accuracy and helps optimization models to best fit planning trade-offs and constraints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address planning technologies, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: Global metals producer\u0026rdquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eUndergo a thorough vendor selection based on a set of functional and nonfunctional selection criteria, including industry use cases, installs, and product deep-dive sessions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSelect the right systems integration partner, particularly one that can handle the complexity and customization necessary to fit the company\u0026rsquo;s needs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eGet an unbiased, high-level view of the envisioned result and map it against the off-the-shelf APS solution. Align on the customization and list requirements that can\u0026rsquo;t be fulfilled.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate the mechanism to achieve impact during solution blueprinting and put extra focus on AA solutions. Because these are often the main value drivers, review applicability and customize as needed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSynchronize the rollout of the APS and the relevant AA solutions by region or business unit, thus maximizing value creation along the journey, potentially self-funding the entire transformation, and boosting its overall net present value.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAs early as the build phase, test that the technology and its various features are functioning correctly. Company product owners should be the final gate to declaring a feature as complete.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTake the time to complete system integration testing, user acceptance testing, and hyper-care (the period immediately following a system change that requires elevated levels of support). This will make your system more robust in the long term.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Capabilities, mindset, and behaviors: How to avoid the return of old habits\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBest-practice processes are typically designed at the start of a project, but once a company reaches the implementation stage of an APS transformation, the target processes are adjusted and people tend to fall back to old ways of working.[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis usually occurs when organizations underestimate the importance of establishing the right internal capabilities to drive an enhanced supply chain or when companies have not established processes for adapting mindsets and behaviors to new ways of working.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo develop talent with more-complex skill profiles, companies can create two new types of capabilities: one with a combination of functional, technical, and leadership competencies to drive performance and another with technical competencies to build, maintain, and develop core AA-model archetypes.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eNext to talent development and capability building, there are three other core elements that embed change into the organization: role modeling management (such as the presence of supply chain and IT directors in key project meetings), embedding change in formal mechanisms (such as disabling old systems), and providing intense support to adopt new ways of working (such as setting up a network of superusers).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address capabilities, mindset, and behaviors, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: Semiconductor producer\u0026rdquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSet up a company-wide communications strategy across multiple channels. As part of change management, strive to create understanding and model best practices.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBe a role model of top management by being present in crucial project governance meetings, leading company communication, and regularly discussing capabilities in executive meetings.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDevelop tailored capability-building programs focused on the specific skills needed. Focus on best practices around planning as well as leadership skills and specific APS software skills.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBlend new competencies, such as data science or data engineering, with training in supply chain management or support from \u0026ldquo;translators\u0026rdquo; who blend functional and digital knowledge.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDevelop a performance management structure that rewards top performers and takes corrective action when performance drops below expectations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCombine specific trainings based on learning material from the APS vendor with in-person classroom trainings for a set of superusers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFacilitate change management in which process improvements will be made over several cycles, enabling incremental adoption of the new mindset and process.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, this type of transformation can have a twofold impact on performance: in addition to the overall improvement of systems and ways of working, the investment in people could generate a substantial return because of increased motivation. Shaping and building solutions that help employees make more effective business decisions in a more efficient way will enable employees to work smarter\u0026mdash;rather than working harder to manually run routine tasks and failing to address complex economic optimization trade-offs in planning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Integrated transformation management: How to avoid project delays and working in silos\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhether a tech-related transformation is for the supply chain or another business function, such transformations are notoriously difficult to get right.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor this reason, value assurance has emerged as a solution for ensuring on-time, on-budget, and on-vision delivery as well as supporting rapid value capture and long-term sustainable impact. Leaders can focus on value-led transformations by implementing guardianship around three distinct, equally important, and mutually reinforcing pillars of responsibility: design, delivery, and value.[[Footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDesign.\u003c/em\u003e Creating a blueprint for success is crucial to effectively managing ingredients of success, such as process and organization, data infrastructure and management, planning technologies, and integrated transformation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDelivery.\u003c/em\u003e Ensuring that system and organizational readiness ultimately stacks up to initial design blueprints, delivery also helps resolve tough design choices regarding customization versus standard system design, enabling rapid end-to-end implementation of the solution across the value chain.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eValue.\u003c/em\u003e Driving successful change management can help establish a value-focused transformation office to ensure cross-functional stakeholder alignment and prioritize actions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith these points in mind, a necessary component of value assurance is building a multidisciplinary team. When it comes to managing the deployment of a wave itself\u0026mdash;for example, planning the blueprint, build, testing, or hyper-care for a certain geography and business unit\u0026mdash;leaders should set up a strong hands-on team, led by someone who can steer a diverse group of people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTypically, an advanced planning transformation requires collaboration among at least three to four different companies\u0026mdash;for instance, a planning software company, a systems integrator, an operating-model consultancy, and a middleware company. It is important that together these companies bring the necessary expertise on all different layers of a digital-planning system. This requires a diverse team set up with more than ten different roles, including industry experts, supply chain planners, solution architects, integration architects, solution configurators, data lake engineers, source system IT, middleware experts, and others.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral factors make this level of collaboration challenging. To begin, it requires a change in mindsets among buyers and suppliers that may be used to more transactional or even adversarial relationships. And most collaborative efforts need intensive, cross-functional involvement from all sides\u0026mdash;a marked change to the normal working methods at many companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address integrated transformation management, companies should take the following actions (for an example, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Example: A metal company\u0026rdquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSet up a project management and project steering committee headed by both IT and the business. Final decision makers, such as the COO and chief technological officer (CTO), can lead the steering committee, removing roadblocks and providing clear direction; project managers can drive top-quality content because of their deep supply chain and ERP expertise.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTake the time to become one team and carve out time to have fun. Have an in-person kickoff to align on roles and responsibilities, deliverables of blueprinting, and ways of working.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEstablish a project management cadence that involves all parties. Key stakeholders of all companies and departments should be present for daily project check-ins, weekly progress reviews, and monthly steering committees.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCreate clearly defined roles and responsibilities. Summarize team roles and their descriptions on one page and the deliverables per role and project phase on another. Buy-in from senior leaders of each company involved can also help hold everyone accountable.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eUse one project management tool that captures the entire workload\u0026mdash;including user requirements, user acceptance testing (UAT) or system-integration-testing cases, issues, and change requests\u0026mdash;and projects along the implementation timeline. Track progress rigorously and reprioritize when needed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTailor the meeting cadence to what is needed per phase of the project\u0026mdash;for example, blueprinting meetings can vary week by week, while testing meetings can be held daily at predefined times and with a consistent agenda. That said, some phases, such as blueprinting and testing, benefit from face-to-face interaction, while others, such as building, are more remote.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImproving cross-functional engagement is a leadership issue. Organizations with the most successful collaboration programs often use a formal approach to managing cross-functional teams, with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This is necessary because a formal approach not only helps ensure that the business does not see the transformation as an IT project but also helps the APS vendor feel accountable for the outcome in terms of its impact on performance and not merely its execution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOld playbooks for transforming supply chain systems are no longer useful, so companies need to think APS transformations through across a broad range of areas. To succeed, it is vital that companies look beyond IT to the transformation process itself: the desired data pipeline, which APS system works best for them, what cultural changes the organization needs, and how collaboration across organizations will work now and in the future.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-20T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMaril\u0026uacute; large global pharmaceutical manufacturer managed to achieve a major inventory reduction, top industry service levels, and improved efficiency through an advanced planning system (APS) transformation. This improvement was made possible by defining overarching standardized end-to-end processes and operating models that were both global and specific to the business units. In particular, the organization worked to change its planning capabilities, such as moving from fragmented to end-to-end planning. Instead of viewing the APS transformation as an IT project and appointing project managers from the business side and IT separately, the organization created a joint team that brought together IT, business leaders, and process consultants. In this way, the organization carried out the APS transformation in parallel with reengineering processes, resulting in agile three-way communication.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Example: Life sciences company"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eAn agricultural company undertook a supply chain transparency project a year before its advanced planning system (APS) implementation. As part of this project, the company integrated data from various sources into its data lake and built best-practice supply chain dashboards to monitor the data quality. Although project leaders struggled with data issues during the dashboarding project, the company was ultimately able to deliver the APS project ahead of time because it could benefit from the work done before. The company was already using the data via the supply chain dashboards, which improved data quality and timeliness. The time gained could then be invested in improving processes and user interface (UI) design.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Example: Large global agricultural company"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eA metals company went through a supply-planning transformation at scale, leveraging advanced planning system (APS) technology. In the design phase, the company concluded that the APS vendor\u0026rsquo;s off-the-shelf algorithm would not suffice to achieve the maximum impact for its future-state process because the company\u0026rsquo;s processes were bespoke. The APS vendor had an open architecture that allowed the company to integrate a bespoke optimization algorithm, which serves as the brain behind the supply plan, while all data structures, user interfaces, data flows, and user interactions were supported by the more standard APS solution. As a result, the company achieved maximum impact by integrating its unique operational constraints, as well as its objectives, while leveraging strong APS standardization and automation of planning processes.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Example: Global metals producer"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"5"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eA leading global semiconductor player embarked on a two-year transformation of its supply chain, upgrading the skills of more than 1,000 employees, many of whom had been working in the organization for 20 to 30 years. The company had no systematic capability-building program in place for experienced staff, and the effort in external hiring had not been able to meet the requirements for the transformation. As the company embarked on a comprehensive supply chain transformation, its leaders suspected that success would depend on a significant shift in the skills and mindsets of its staff. By running a detailed assessment of the company\u0026rsquo;s workforce capabilities, the company was able to set up a two-year capability-building road map segmented by target population, functional knowledge, and level of expertise. In doing so, workforce capabilities dramatically increased, and the gap to initial state was closed, ensuring the success of the transformation program.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Example: Semiconductor producer"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"6"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe advanced planning system (APS) implementation for a metal company involved a collaboration among three organizations: the metal company itself, the APS, and the value assurance or integration partner. To ensure that all three companies were working as one team, the collaboration established a single project governance with one overall project manager and one overall project steering committee (with combined business and IT functions). This avoided siloed ways of working and misaligned priorities. The project manager worked hand in hand with the APS technical lead to set the priorities and define business requirements, while the technical lead defined technical requirements, ensured solution quality, and gave input on workload. As a result, the team was able to work in a synchronized way and deliver the project on time.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Example: A
